prior_works.title: Optimization and Nonsmooth Analysis
prior_works.role: Foundation for Clarke subdifferential and stationarity in nonsmooth analysis
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s target notion—Clarke hyper-stationarity—rests directly on Clarke’s generalized gradient and stationarity concepts, which enable defining and computing stationarity for the nonsmooth hyper-objective induced by bilevel problems.

prior_works.title: Variational Analysis
prior_works.authors: R. Tyrrell Rockafellar, Roger J-B Wets
prior_works.role: Core variational/set-valued tools and weak convexity framework
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The authors leverage variational analysis of marginal/value functions, set-valued mappings, prox-regularity, and weak convexity from this text to formalize the hyper-objective as a marginal function and to justify weak convexity/concavity once their set-smoothness property holds.

prior_works.title: Strongly Regular Generalized Equations
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Robinson’s strong regularity and implicit-function theory for generalized equations underpin modern criteria for Lipschitz-like dependence of solution sets on parameters, a direct antecedent to the paper’s set smoothness property capturing variational dependence of the lower-level solution set.

prior_works.title: Perturbation Analysis of Optimization Problems
prior_works.role: Sensitivity/differentiability of value functions and Danskin-type envelopes
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The treatment of marginal functions and envelope/Danskin-type results here provides the classical pathway to differentiable hyper-objectives under strong assumptions; the new work explicitly removes those assumptions and replaces them with set smoothness while retaining subdifferential characterizations.

prior_works.title: Optimality Conditions for Bilevel Programming Problems
prior_works.role: Value-function/hyper-objective perspective and stationarity in bilevel programs
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This seminal paper established value-function reformulations and stationarity notions for bilevel programs, laying the conceptual groundwork that the present paper refines to Clarke hyper-stationarity for nonsmooth hyper-objectives without uniqueness or smoothness of the lower level.

prior_works.title: Stochastic Subgradient Methods for Nonconvex, Nonsmooth Optimization under Weak Convexity
prior_works.role: Algorithmic machinery for computing Clarke-stationary points of weakly convex functions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By showing convergence of (prox-)subgradient methods to Clarke stationary points under weak convexity, this line of work becomes applicable once the paper proves the hyper-objective is weakly convex/concave via set smoothness, enabling computable Clarke hyper-stationarity.

prior_works.title: Hyperparameter Optimization with Approximate Gradient
prior_works.role: Implicit differentiation of argmin maps under restrictive smooth/strongly convex assumptions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work exemplifies the prevailing approach that requires strong convexity and smoothness of the lower-level to obtain smooth hypergradients; the new paper explicitly lifts these restrictions by working with nonsmooth hyper-objectives and Clarke calculus enabled by set smoothness.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core contribution—computable Clarke hyper-stationarity for bilevel optimization without demanding smooth or unique lower-level solutions—sits at the intersection of classical nonsmooth analysis, parametric optimization, and modern weak-convexity algorithms. Clarke’s foundational framework for generalized gradients provides the exact stationarity notion the authors target when the hyper-objective is nonsmooth. Rockafellar and Wets, together with Bonnans and Shapiro, supply the variational and perturbation-analysis toolkit for marginal (value) functions and set-valued mappings; these ideas motivate modeling the hyper-objective as a value function and clarifying how its subdifferential and curvature properties arise from the parametric dependence of the solution set. Robinson’s strong regularity and implicit-function theory for generalized equations directly inspire the paper’s set smoothness concept, which captures Lipschitz-like and variational stability of the lower-level solution map without requiring uniqueness or strong convexity.

Within bilevel optimization specifically, Ye and Zhu established value-function reformulations and stationarity principles that the present work extends to the Clarke setting. Crucially, once set smoothness guarantees weak convexity (pessimistic) or weak concavity (optimistic) of the hyper-objective, the algorithmic pathway opened by Davis and Drusvyatskiy’s weakly convex optimization results becomes available to compute Clarke-stationary solutions. Finally, prior implicit-differentiation approaches such as Pedregosa’s highlight the limitations of smooth/strongly-convex assumptions that this paper overcomes, replacing classical smooth hypergradients with robust Clarke subdifferential calculus grounded in set smoothness.
